Massachusetts General Laws c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts General Laws c. 186 and c. 239 and is responsible for compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

c. 239.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts General Laws c. 186 and c. 239 and is responsible for compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.raw_text: Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts General Laws c. 186 and c. 239 and is responsible for compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14..proposition: This is an action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A,.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A, the Worcester District Court has jurisdiction over this matter because the Premises are located in Worcester, Massachusetts, and the claims arose within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

105 C.M.R. 410.550 and 410.600..proposition: The presence of mouse droppings is evidence of ongoing rodent infestation, which constitutes a condition that may endanger or materially impair the health, safety, or well-being of the occupants in violation of the State Sanitary Code, including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.550 and 410.600.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes an implied warranty of habitability and an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: Hemingway is the seminal Massachusetts case recognizing an implied warranty of habitability in residential tenancies, and this concurrence agrees that the common-law rule of no implied agreement of fitness for occupancy should be reversed. However, the quoted text is from a concurring/dissenting opinion that critiques the majority’s formulation and would instead tie the landlord’s obligation strictly to statutory and code standards, and it does not itself discuss or ground an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case overall supports the habitability-warranty portion of the proposition (via the majority), but this excerpt alone does not clearly support either the warranty or the quiet enjoyment covenant.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair … The tenant takes the premises as he finds them and there is no obligation on the landlord to make repairs.’ … As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule…”

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., adopted pursuant to G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, establishes minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, including requirements related to vermin and rodent control.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: The State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., adopted pursuant to G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, establishes minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, including requirements related to vermin and rodent control.

Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199\u2013200.proposition: Violations of the State Sanitary Code can constitute evidence of a breach of the warranty of habitability and can support a finding of a substantial interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199–200; Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–02 (1979).

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–02 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Violations of the State Sanitary Code can constitute evidence of a breach of the warranty of habitability and can support a finding of a substantial interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199–200; Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–02 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties habitability and rent abatement to compliance with the State Sanitary Code, stating that a dwelling with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable and that the landlord must at least comply with minimum State building and sanitary code standards. While the case is focused on breach of the warranty of habitability and rent abatement rather than G.L. c. 186, §14 quiet enjoyment, it clearly holds that Sanitary Code violations are the benchmark for determining breach of the warranty and thus are evidence of substantial interference with the tenant’s rights. Together with Hemingway (also cited in the proposition), it supports using Sanitary Code violations as evidence of breach of the warranty and substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. … [W]hen the defect occurs in the rented premises, the question is not one of negligence, but one of breach of warranty. In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–06 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–86 (1994).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court explicitly ties the landlord’s statutory and common-law duty to maintain sanitary, habitable conditions (including compliance with the State Sanitary Code’s watertight requirement) to the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It holds that Gem is liable under § 14 because it violated its duty to maintain sanitary conditions and allowed repeated flooding that interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, thereby recognizing that failure to correct serious sanitary code violations after notice can constitute a breach/interference with quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found … that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–86 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–06 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–86 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does so in the context of criminal/drug activity and the landlord’s failure to take measures to remove nontenants, not in the context of failure to correct State Sanitary Code violations or serious physical conditions after notice. The court’s quiet-enjoyment analysis turns on whether the landlord’s inaction regarding third-party unlawful activity can be a serious interference with tenancy, and the State Sanitary Code is addressed only as a benchmark for the warranty of habitability, which the court holds is not breached here. Thus, this case does not stand for the specific proposition that failure to correct serious sanitary-code violations after notice constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment; that principle comes from Simon v. Solomon, not from Doe.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”}

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment focuses on whether the landlord engaged in acts or omissions that substantially interfered with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, and does not require physical entry or eviction. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716–18 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in terms of the landlord’s acts or omissions and their natural and probable consequences, explicitly deemphasizing the landlord’s subjective intent. The court finds a breach based on substantial interference with use (noise from a lounge the landlord enabled and could control), without any physical entry or formal eviction, and treats that as constructive eviction/violation of quiet enjoyment. This aligns with the proposition that the focus is on substantial interference by landlord conduct or omission and does not require physical entry or actual eviction.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Blackett, 371 Mass. at 716\u201318.proposition: Where a landlord’s conduct or failure to act, after notice, foreseeably and substantially impairs the character and value of the leased premises for the tenant’s purposes, the landlord has breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 716–18; Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–52 (1997).

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Where a landlord’s conduct or failure to act, after notice, foreseeably and substantially impairs the character and value of the leased premises for the tenant’s purposes, the landlord has breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 716–18; Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–52 (1997).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reiterates that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires at least negligent conduct by the landlord, with notice or reason to know of the problem, and that the natural and probable (i.e., foreseeable) consequences of the failure to act must be interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This matches the proposition that, after notice, a landlord’s conduct or inaction that foreseeably and substantially impairs the character and value of the premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, building on Blackett and related cases.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.… We have also said that § 14 imposes liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Under G.L. c. 239, § 8A, sanitary code violations and conditions materially affecting the health or safety of tenants may support claims and defenses, including breach of warranty and quiet enjoyment; the same conditions may form the basis of affirmative relief where, as here, a tenant seeks damages for loss of use and enjoyment.

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908–09 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: In addition, Massachusetts appellate courts have recognized that persistent infestations and unsanitary conditions—such as rodents, insects, and other vermin—may constitute substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment and support recovery under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908–09 (1987) (rodent infestation and code violations); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994) (habitability and code compliance as to vermin).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The case does involve unsanitary conditions including "mice" and "ants" as State Sanitary Code violations and affirms a damage award for breach of the warranty of habitability based on code violations. However, the opinion does not explicitly analyze those vermin conditions as substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14; instead it discusses them under habitability/rent abatement and notes many violations had only "minimal impact." Thus the case somewhat indirectly, but not squarely, supports the general idea that such conditions are actionable, though not specifically under § 14.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property.2 The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.
...
The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks.

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: In addition, Massachusetts appellate courts have recognized that persistent infestations and unsanitary conditions—such as rodents, insects, and other vermin—may constitute substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment and support recovery under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g., Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908–09 (1987) (rodent infestation and code violations); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994) (habitability and code compliance as to vermin).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The case holds that the landlord’s failure to correct numerous sanitary, building, and fire code violations—including a “serious infestation of vermin”—constituted a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 because it substantially impaired the value of the leased premises. The court expressly links these habitability and code-compliance issues (including vermin) to liability under the covenant of quiet enjoyment, thereby supporting the proposition that such unsanitary conditions can be a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment under § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, **which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin**, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. **On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.**”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), a landlord’s willful or reckless failure to remedy serious conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of their home can give rise to liability for not only economic loss, but also for emotional distress and discomfort caused by the breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “actual and consequential damages” language to include personal, not just economic, harms and explicitly holds that emotional distress from unsanitary, flood conditions that interfere with quiet enjoyment is compensable. It states that consequential damages under § 14 encompass all reasonably foreseeable losses, "personal as well as economic," and applies that reading to Simon’s (Solomon’s) emotional distress caused by the landlord’s reckless failure to correct the flooding, linking that harm to the breach of quiet enjoyment. Although the separate emotional-distress count provided an overlapping tort recovery, the opinion clearly recognizes emotional distress as an element of damages flowing from the statutory quiet-enjoyment violation.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises.... The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery. In the present case, not only were Solomon’s injuries foreseeable, but the jury found specifically that Gem knew or should have known that if it permitted floods to occur, Solomon would suffer emotional harm. Therefore, Solomon’s claim for emotional distress was within the scope of § 14…”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: By statute, a tenant prevailing on a claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is entitled to actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; see also Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979).
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14, explaining that a landlord who violates the statute is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” The court rejects the trial judge’s multiplier approach and clarifies that the statute provides a minimum of three months’ rent when actual and consequential damages are less, but otherwise actual damages control, and in all events costs and reasonable attorney’s fees are recoverable. This directly matches the proposition stated.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’… Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove. When the actual damages exceed three months’ rent, however, § 14 plainly states that actual damages should be the measure of recovery.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff invokes these authorities and the protections of G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000), G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and relevant case law, including but not limited to:
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The proposition lists a bundle of statutory and regulatory authorities (G.L. c. 186, § 14; State Sanitary Code; G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; G.L. c. 239, § 8A) as protections invoked by a plaintiff. Darmetko does interpret and apply G.L. c. 186, § 14 regarding quiet enjoyment, damages, and attorney’s fees, but it does not discuss the State Sanitary Code, G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, or G.L. c. 239, § 8A at all. Thus it can only support reliance on c. 186, § 14, not the broader, inclusive list stated in the proposition.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "The judge further ruled that the leaks in the roof (but not the defective floors) interfered with the plaintiffs quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. Because of this interference, and based on his reading of G. L. c. 186, § 14, the judge ruled that the plaintiff was entitled to an additional $5,358... The judge’s conclusion that, under G. L. c. 186, § 14, as amended by St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, the plaintiff could recover three times her monthly rental obligation for each month during which the leaks remained unrepaired is incorrect. Section 14 provides that a lessor... shall 'be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.'"

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff invokes these authorities and the protections of G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000), G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and relevant case law, including but not limited to:
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The quoted passage from Berman & Sons v. Jefferson discusses the common-law implied warranty of habitability, rent abatement, and the interaction with G.L. c. 239, § 8A and the State Sanitary Code, but it does not itself involve a tenant “invoking” or asserting claims directly under G.L. c. 186, § 14, or under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L as independent causes of action. The case uses those statutes and the Code primarily as background and legislative context for the warranty of habitability and rent abatement doctrine. Thus, it does not directly support a proposition that a plaintiff is invoking and proceeding under those statutory protections in the way the proposition suggests.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “For example, the State Sanitary Code, adopted pursuant to authority granted in G. L. c. 111, § 5 (since amended, see G. L. c. 111, § 127A, for the current version), imposed on the landlord a duty to maintain an apartment in habitable condition… Moreover, the Legislature had created tenant’s remedies for private enforcement of the Code, G. L. c. 111, §§ 127A-127H, and for self-help through rent withholding, G. L. c. 239, § 8A…. The rent-withholding provision embodies a legislative judgment that the tenant’s rental obligation is bound up with the landlord’s obligation to provide habitable premises.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Plaintiff invokes these authorities and the protections of G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000), G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and relevant case law, including but not limited to:
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The proposition refers to statutory protections under G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code, G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and related case law. Blackett v. Olanoff is a common-law constructive eviction/quiet enjoyment case and does not interpret, apply, or even mention these statutes or the State Sanitary Code. It is relevant background landlord-tenant authority on constructive eviction and quiet enjoyment, but it does not support the specific statutory-based proposition as framed.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff invokes these authorities and the protections of G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000), G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and relevant case law, including but not limited to:
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The proposition lists G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code, G.L. c. 111 §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and ‘relevant case law’ as invoked authorities. Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority does interpret and apply G.L. c. 186, § 14 (quiet enjoyment), but it does not involve or construe the State Sanitary Code, G.L. c. 111 §§ 127A–127L, or G.L. c. 239, § 8A, nor does it tie those provisions together as a combined set of protections. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for that aggregated proposition, though it is proper authority only as to c. 186, § 14 and habitability/quiet enjoyment concepts.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14. There must be a trial to determine what, if any, measures the defendant has taken to remove nontenants engaged in unlawful activity and to determine the seriousness or substantiality of the interference with the tenancies. If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action… then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.proposition: Plaintiff invokes these authorities and the protections of G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000), G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and relevant case law, including but not limited to:
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.support_reasoning: The proposition is a generic string indicating that plaintiff invokes G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code, G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and ‘relevant case law.’ Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas does address and apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not discuss or apply the State Sanitary Code regulations, G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, or G.L. c. 239, § 8A. Thus the case cannot fairly be cited as authority for invoking that entire collection of statutory and regulatory protections, only for the c. 186, § 14 aspect and related habitability/93A principles.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.relevant_excerpt: “Thomas claimed that conditions in her apartment violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown. On remand, Thomas is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees on this basis.… From May, 1988, through October, 1990… conditions in the apartment violated numerous provisions of the State Sanitary Code.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Plaintiff invokes these authorities and the protections of G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000), G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and relevant case law, including but not limited to:
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The proposition lists G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code, G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and “relevant case law” as protective authorities. Al‑Ziab addresses only whether a violation of the lead paint statute (G.L. c. 111, §§ 190 et seq.) automatically constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and holds that it does not; it does not discuss the State Sanitary Code, §§ 127A–127L, or c. 239, § 8A. Thus, it does not support the broad proposition invoked by the plaintiff and in fact limits the use of § 14 in this context.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Plaintiff invokes these authorities and the protections of G.L. c. 186, § 14, the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000), G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and relevant case law, including but not limited to:
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Young v. Patukonis discusses specific issues: enforceability of an oral agreement for tenant-provided heat under the State Sanitary Code, violations of the security deposit statute (G.L. c. 186, § 15B), Boston rent control ordinance remedies, warranty of habitability damages, and inapplicability of G.L. c. 93A to an owner‑occupant. It does not cite or interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14; G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; or G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and thus does not support the proposition that the plaintiff is invoking “these authorities” or that this case is authority concerning those specific statutory protections.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. . . . The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling “shall” supply heat and hot water “except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.” . . . In finding that Young violated the requirements of the security deposit statute, the judge limited the tenant’s damage award to interest of $5.21.
